title.narrative: Kvinnors ekonomiska egenmakt genom stärkande av marknadssystem
Women's Economic Empowerment through Strengthening Market Systems

description.narrative:
Det övergripande syftet med insatsen “Kvinnors ekonomiska egenmakt genom stärkande av marknadssystem”, WEESMS (Women’s Economic Empowerment through Strengthening Market Systems) är att förbättra möjligheterna för produktiva arbetstillfällen för kvinnor på arbetsmarknaden genom att öka antalet och tillväxten av kvinnligt ledda småföretag, förbättra kvinnors tillgång till produktiv sysselsättning, hålla kvar kvinnor på arbetsmarknaden samt utöka kvinnliga småföretagares tillgång till banklån. Insatsen består av tre komponenter: 1) WEESMS-projektet, 2) en kreditgaranti och 3) en extern utvärdering. Detta beslut avser de två komponenterna WEESMS-projektet och den externa utvärderingen. Insatsen löper på fem år med start i juli 2016 till och med juni 2021 inklusive en inledningsfas på tio månader för WEESMS-projektet. Kreditgarantikomponenten kommer att beredas i särskild ordning och tilläggsbeslut planeras till oktober 2016 för gåvomedel till tekniskt stöd och subvention av garantiavgiften samt beslut om garantiåtagandet.
WEESMS-projektet kommer att genomföras av ett konsortium bestående av de två internationella NGO:erna International Development Enterprises (iDE) och The Asia Foundation (TAF) i nära samarbete med statliga institutioner, kvinnliga handelskammare, privata företag och intresseorganisationer. iDE kommer att leda konsortiet och vara Sida:s avtalspartner. Kreditgarantin planeras att hanteras av den bangladeshiska centralbanken (Bangladesh Bank) i nära samarbete med Asiatiska utvecklingsbanken (ADB) och kommer att erbjudas utvalda finansiella institutioner. Det planerade garantiåtagandet uppgår till motsvarande 15 miljoner dollar, motsvarande 130 miljoner SEK och är nära sammankopplat med ett ADB-projekt som syftar till att låna ut minst 20 miljoner dollar, motsvarande 170 miljoner SEK till kvinnliga småföretagare genom Bangladesh Bank under 2016-2020. Syftet med kreditgarantin är att förbättra tillgången till investeringskapital för kvinnliga småföretagare till lägre ränta än marknadsräntan och lägre krav på säkerhet. WEESMS-projektet och kreditgarantin kommer att vara ömsesidigt understödjande till insatsen men inte beroende av varandra.
WEESMS-projektet har en ambition att åstadkomma marknadssystemförändringar genom att adressera de huvudsakliga hinder kvinnliga företagare möter för att utveckla sina företag, kunna anställa fler kvinnliga medarbetare samt bibehålla kvinnor på arbetsmarknaden. Projektet använder flera innovativa tillvägagångssätt för att uppnå hållbara resultat såsom att tillämpa en marknadssystemutvecklingsansats (Making Markets Work for the Poor, M4P) i kombination med metoder för att stärka kvinnors ekonomiska egenmakt (Women’s Economic Empowerment, WEE). Projektet kommer även att säkerställa att anständiga arbetsvillkor och att miljömässigt hållbara verksamheter främjas samt att tillämpa både ett konfliktkänslighets- och ett resiliensperspektiv. Projektet kommer att använda DCED:s (Donor Committee for Enterprise Development) standard som grund för resultatuppföljningen.
WEESMS-projektet kommer att fokusera på 3-4 affärssektorer på landsbygden (rural) och stadsnära områden (peri-urban) där det finns goda möjligheter för kvinnors företagande och öka kvinnors deltagande på arbetsmarknaden. Grundliga analyser kommer att göras under föreberedelsefasen av projektet, i syfte att identifiera de bakomliggande orsakerna till varför marknadssystemet inte gynnar kvinnliga småföretagare och kvinnors deltagande på arbetsmarknaden samt för att identifiera affärsmöjligheter i de utvalda sektorerna. Detta kommer att leda till en tydlig förståelse för de problem som skall lösas och utveckling av interventionsstrategier som ska styra projekts aktiviteter.
Projektaktiviteterna kommer att baseras på ett brett spektrum av faktorer relaterade till WEE: å ena sidan, teknisk kompetens och ekonomiska möjligheter och å andra sidan, psykosociala faktorer. Aktiviteterna kommer att vara inriktade mot att skapa gynnsamma miljöer för kvinnliga företagare och arbetare genom kapacitetsutveckling av företagsnätverk, arbetarorganisationer och handelskammare. Vidare kommer projektet genom kompetensutveckling att stärka målgruppens kunskaper och förmåga att driva sitt företag. Projektet kommer att stödja kvinnor att hävda sina rättigheter samt arbeta för att förebygga våld mot kvinnor genom att medvetandegöra män, lokala ledare och religiösa företrädare. Projektet kommer att tillämpa en så kallad faciliterande metod för att genomföra marknadsutvecklingsaktiviteter såsom att upprätta kopplingar till olika typer av företagstjänster och storföretag, introducera ny teknik och kunskap, förbättra tillgången till information och kommunikation genom IT-tjänster, tillhandahålla kapacitetsutveckling av privata och offentliga aktörer, stimulera förändring av attityder och kulturella normer samt förbättra möjligheten för kvinnliga företagare att kunna få banklån.
Den sammanlagda budgeten för insatsen är 65,2 miljoner kronor, varav 64 miljoner kronor avsätts för WEESMS-projektet och 1,2 miljoner kronor avsätts för en extern utvärdering.

The overall objective of the intervention “Women’s Economic Empowerment through Strengthening Market Systems” is to increase productive work opportunities for women in the labour market by increasing the number and the growth of women-led small businesses, improving women's access to productive employment, increasing retention rates of women in the labour market, and enhancing access to bank finance for women-led micro and small-sized enterprises. The intervention consists of three components; 1) the WEESMS programme, 2) a credit guarantee, and 3) an external evaluation. This decision concerns the two components WEESMS programme and the external evaluation. The intervention runs for five years starting in July 2016 to June 2021 including an inception phase of ten months for the WEESMS programme. The credit guarantee component will be appraised separately and additional decisions are scheduled for October 2016 for support to technical assistance and subsidy of the credit guarantee fee as well as the decision on the frame for the credit guarantee.
The WEESMS programme will be implemented by a consortium of international NGOs, International Development Enterprises (iDE) and The Asia Foundation (TAF) in close cooperation with government institutions, women’s chambers of commerce, private companies and NGOs. iDE will lead the consortium and thus be Sida's agreement partner. The planned credit guarantee will be handled by the Bangladesh Bank, the central bank, in close collaboration with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and will be offered to selected financial institutions. The credit guarantee is planned to be 15 million USD and is linked to an ADB project which aims to lend at least 20 million USD to women small business owners through the Bangladesh Bank during 2016-2020. The purpose of the credit guarantee is to improve access to financial services for women small business owners with lower level of interest rate and lower collateral. The WEESMS programme and the credit guarantee are equally supportive to the intervention but not dependent of each other.
The programme has an ambition to achieve market system changes by addressing the main barriers that women entrepreneurs face in developing their business, be able to hire more female workers, and to increase the retention rate of women in the labour market. The programme uses several innovative approaches to achieve sustainable results, such as applying a market systems development approach (Making Markets Work for the Poor, M4P) integrated with methods to strengthen women's economic empowerment (WEE). The programme will also ensure that decent working conditions and environmentally sustainable business practices are promoted as well as to apply a conflict sensitive and a resilience perspective. The programme will use the DCED’s (Donor Committee for Enterprise Development) Standard as the basis for its performance monitoring.
The programme will focus on 3-4 business sectors in rural and peri-urban areas where there are good opportunities for women’s entrepreneurship and to increase women’s participation in the labour market. Thorough market systems and gender analyses will be carried out during the inception phase to identify the underlying causes for why the market system is not benefitting small and medium-sized women entrepreneurs and women participation in the labour market as well as to identify the business opportunities in the selected sectors. This will lead to a clear understanding of what issues that needs to be addressed and to development of intervention strategies that will guide the implementation activities.

The programme will apply a facilitation methodology for carrying out market development activities such as establishing links with different types of service providers and large companies, introducing new technology and knowledge, improving access to information and communication, providing capacity building of private and public partners, providing access to skills development, stimulating change of mind-set and cultural norms, improving access to bank loans and business services, and strengthening business networks and women’s chambers of commerce.
The programme activities will be based on a wide range of factors related to WEE; on the one hand, technological skills and economic opportunities and, on the other hand, psychosocial factors. The activities will be focused on creating enabling environments for women entrepreneurs and workers through capacity development of business networks, workers' organisations and chambers of commerce. Furthermore, the programme will through competence development strengthen the target group's knowledge and ability to operate its business. The programme will support women to assert their rights and to prevent violence against women through awareness raising activities among men, local leaders and religious representatives. The project will apply a facilitative approach to conduct market development activities such as the establishment of links to different types of business services and large companies, introduce new technology and knowledge, improving access to communications and information technology, providing capacity development of private and public actors, encouraging change in attitudes and cultural norms as well as to improve women entrepreneurs’ opportunities to get bank loans.
The total budget for the intervention is 65,2 million SEK, whereof 64 million SEK is allocated for the WEESMS programme and, 1.2 million SEK for an external outcome evaluation.

Year 2020 was one of the most impactful phases for WEESMSs (Women's Economic Empowerment through Strengthening Market Systems) project, as they planned and designed their interventions in a way that can lead to a responsible exit of the project in 2021 in line with its contractual closing. Unfortunately, before any major programmatic activities could take place, the global outbreak of COVID-19 pandemic halted all field activities. This global health crisis had not only limited the ability of the project to accelerate the growth of the SMEs that it engages with but has also impacted the SMEs supported by the project heavily as they have lost crucial seasonal sales due to nation-wide lockdown, thus also limiting the project staffs outputs to redesigning the interventions to COVID-19 responses.
Annual progress survey 2019-2020 (took place in January 2021), reveals that 493 SMEs out of 540 SMEs are co-implementing decent work practices at their workplace with support from WEESMS facilitated partnerships and 90 percent of workers from women-led/owned SMEs and 100 percent from women-oriented SMEs confirmed the implementation of decent work practices in their factory premises. To strengthen the resilience of women-led/owned & women-oriented SMEs to overcome economic shocks, 90 percent of the SMEs had reinvested their savings and with support from WEESMS facilitated linkages, skills and partnerships with different financial institutes, more than 50 SMEs could successfully manage to afford financial support or loan of the Government of Bangladesh COVID 19 stimulus packages. It was also revealed that, 80 percent of the SMEs were able to retain their workers gradually as the lockdown restrictions were lifted and businesses came back to normal scale. However, the remaining 20 percent have only partially gone back to their original scale of operations and have not been able to accommodate their original employee pool, mostly comprising home-based contractual women workers.
The report shows some important figures relating to achievements between 2019 to 2020 following the annual progress survey while we expect to see figures showing the implementation in 2020- for example, figures for the number of new SMEs engaged and new employment opportunities created in 2020 are yet not available. The Embassy realizes that the project had to stop their field operation for around four months and had to change the goal structure of the project due to COVID pandemic, however, the Embassy still expects to receive data concerning the period.
The report also shows that the project was too overly reliant on outputs rather than its outcomes. The project team was giving too much focus on curbing symptoms of a flawed market system, rather than focusing on addressing root causes impeding the sustainable development and expansion of the targeted SMEs in the market system.
Responsible Programme Officer has brought forward the questions and concerns to the WEESMS team during the 2021 workplan meeting and the WEESMS team also replied and provided clarifications and justifications of the concerns. As 2021 is the last year of the project and an independent end-term evaluation is on-going, the assigned Programme Officer will have a close dialogue and monitoring of the outcome of the reminder of the project.

title.narrative: Women's Economic Empowerment through Strengthening Market System

description.narrative: In 2019, the Women's Economic Empowerment through Strengthening Market Systems (WEESMS) programme reached the mid-way point in its current programme cycle. During this year the intervention activities were designed in reference to the programme’s 2018 Theory of Change which conceptualized three Outcome-level Goals for WEESMS: Outcome 1: Increase the number of women entrepreneurs and growth of women-oriented/led businesses (SMEs) in target sector; Outcome 2: Improve women’s access to formal and informal productive employment opportunities in target sectors; Outcome 3: Increase retention rates of women in labour market in target sectors. WEESMS has pursued these outcomes by implementing activities under 8 Intervention Areas. This Conclusion on Performance has been prepared based on the annual report 2019, reports on different studies, mid-term assessment and one field visit conducted during December 2019. Here are the summary of progresses that project made during 2019: During 2019, the project produced a number of output-level results. For example, work towards the outcome of "Increased number of women entrepreneurs and growth of women-oriented/ led businesses (SMEs) in target sectors" 330 women-led/owned SMEs from the two target sectors (Jute Diversified Product sector and Processed and Packaged Foods sector) received business development services on business planning and financial management. In addition, eight different organizations/ companies began to offer a range of business development services to these SMEs. In partnering with Bagdoom (one of the largest e-commerce platforms in the country) and Prokritee (a national fair-trade company), the project has leveraged output market linkages for women-led/owned and women-oriented SMEs. In 2019, SMEs generated BDT 14,220,546 (equivalent to USD 171,332) in sales that can be attributed to WEESMS support through participation in trade fairs - Regional and National - e-commerce sales, and Business-to-Business (B2B) sales through Prokritee. The project worked with a few local business owners in larger agglomerations to incite them function as ‘Input Hub’s for surrounding smaller SMEs with the aim of facilitating access to a larger variety of inputs closer to the location of these SMEs. To increase rural SMEs access to financial service and products, the project initiated financial literacy training services in the target regions (75 WEESMS-associated women-led/owned SMEs had availed loans from 31 different financial institutions with the loan-size ranging from BDT 50,000 to BDT 1,200,000: totaling BDT 17,860,000- equivalent to USD 215,180). Additionally, it continued to cooperate informally with public sector actors, including the SME Foundation (Bangladesh government supported foundation under the Ministry of Commerce), different local City Corporations and Chambers of Commerce, by facilitating linkages between SMEs and the activities that these public actors are offering such as trade fairs and training workshops. To increase women employees/potential employees access to improved skills, knowledge and facilities for decent work, the project facilitated 6 exposure visits in order to facilitate an opportunity for 43 women- oriented SMEs to learn from the practical experiences of other employers about how to implement elements of decent work, as well as the benefits such changes will bring to the business. The project delivered Gender Sensitization and Decent Work training to 30 women-oriented SMEs and 3,953 women employees. For 76% of SME owners (all male) that participated in the training stated that this training was the first time they had encountered decent work concepts. SMEs are steering staff meetings on periodic basis which is creating opportunity for women employees to communicate their concerns directly with their employers and raise their voice to advocate for improved working conditions. The women-oriented SMEs who are engaged in year 2018 and 2019 through WEESMS have started taking various initiatives to make workplace more conducive for women workers. Based on the 2018 Annual Survey report, it indicates more than 50% of the women-oriented SMEs have taken initiatives to installing first aid kits, creating women’s only restrooms, hiring security guards, and providing essential safety equipment and training to employees. More than 40% of the women-oriented SMEs have taken initiatives to provide health checkup facilities, masks and aprons, and weekly holidays. To promote an enabling environment for women entrepreneurs and women workers, the project facilitated several gender sensitization sessions with families of women-led/ owned SMEs and employees as well as with family members of employees (2525 household members- 80% female and 20% male were reached through 50 sensitization events conducted by community gender advocates). The sessions address how to broach difficult topics, as well as provide positive examples for family members who may not be supportive of the engagement of female household members in business. Gender sensitization dialogues for employees were aimed at making participants more aware of gender dynamics and to help create safe spaces for discussion about experiences and challenges faced by employees in the workplace and at home. Micro and cottage level women-led/ owned SME owners respondents who participated in the internal impact assessment survey reported significant positive changes among their family members: 75% indicated that their family encourages them to put time into growing their business, 74% indicated that the family encourages them to attend training, workshops or other networking events, 67% reported that their family recognizes that unpaid household work should be shared more evenly between men and women, and 59% indicated that other family members assist in unpaid household care work. In 2019, the project began to test a “Women Sales Agents”-model by partnering with the social enterprise iSocial to identify, train and support rural women to sell and deliver essential consumer products and services targeted at particular needs of women, children and adolescent girls. With a view to facilitate Public-Private Policy Dialogues (PPDs) on issues that affect women’s productive workforce participation the project first engaged SMEs and other stakeholders in dialogues to identify policy issues. The Central Bank- Bangladesh Bank’s SME specific credit policies to women-led/owned SMEs requiring collateral and guarantor when availing loans was such an issue. The project organized a national level public-private dialogue to identify both gaps and touch points between local and national agendas and engage them in policy dialogues to develop common consensus in endorsing the challenges and work collaboratively to mitigate those. The national dialogues engaged influential stakeholders in the banking sector. The articulation of a policy issue (SME loan guarantor requirements), related policy advocacy dialogues, and issuance of a Bangladesh Bank circular on the matter, represent significant progress on this intervention area for 2019.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
